reviewText:
Wow. There are a lot of unhappy bunnies out there. Silence of the Lambs is, in my view, one of the great thrillers. It is, however, NOT a horror movie.
That's not to say it isn't grisly, but there are no monsters about  to leap out of the closet (well, apart from Hannibal) and tear you apart.  Much of the violence is gruesome rather than scary, and adds to the general  feel of the film.
I can understand totally people who dislike the film.  It was hyped to a great degree when released, and a lot of people expected  a chase 'n' slash horror. It was never meant to be that.
The comparison  to Psycho is purely valid and perhaps one of the most telling. Psycho did  use chase 'n' slash horror as well as the more morbid psychological horror  (mainly engineered by Hitchcock). SOTL relies far more heavily on the  latter, and brings it off far more effectively.
The only true chase scene  is in the final five minutes: heroine against villain. Even Lecters escape  is more of a planned action rather than a bloodfest, which happens to  involve murder because it was required in the plan. Even Lecters unseen  murders (as were Bill's) were carried out as a necessary means to an end  (to eat flesh or to skin them).
I'm sure that this review will generate  it's own barrage of response to counter my points. But my final thought on  this is: Art is intended not only to appeal aesthetically, but to stimulate  discussion and thought. If this film has done this, then can it be  considered art? If not, then surely it should just be enjoyed as it is; a  modern thriller.

Absolutely as scary a movie as Hollywood could ever produce.  The acting, writing, cinematography, and dramatic lighting effects are awesome.  The story, based on my favorite book by Thomas Harris of the same title, is  incredibly chilling. FBI trainee Clarice Starling (Jodie Foster) is  assigned to an interview with "Hannibal The Cannibal" Lecter  (Anthony Hopkins), who is, without a doubt, the completely immoral  personification of evil.  Hopefully, Lecter will aid in the capture of  another grizzly murderer who skins his victims.  The plot twists and turns  as will your stomach.  However the explict and grizzly visuals are sumptous  rather than repulsive.  However, this film still can not be recommended to  the squeamish.  Anthony Hopkins makes the most of his part and leaves you  with an impression that will haunt you forever.  If you like the movie,  read the book alone in the dark, which will also send chills up your spine.  Nightmares Gaurenteed!
The movie also won five accolodes from the  Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.  Including Anthony Hopkins  only Oscar which he won for Best Actor, and Jodie Foster's for Best  Actress.  It even won Best Picture of the Year.

Anthony Hopkins is at his best in this thriller about a serial killer who keeps luring the police and FBI off course.  Jodie Foster does an outstanding performance as an FBI special agent who uses Hopkins to catch  the serial killer.  I love this movie and I will watch it over and over.

If you are a serious movie lover, you must see this movie.  The DVD  transfer is very good, and you'll see facial expression details that could  not be seen on VHS (even with the best equipment).  END

Travel into the world of Clarise Starling, a smart and attractive FBI trainee who is eagerly waiting for her graduation so she can become an agant for the Behavioral Science section of the FBI. She is sent on a mission from the BS sections cheif Jack Crawford to try to get some case information from one of the most famous crimminals ever, Dr. Hannibal Lecter, a.k.a. "Hannibal the Cannibal", a genius serial killer who ate parts of his victims. Clarise is hoping to get some information on another killer, nicknamed "Buffalo Bill", who has been killing women and doing strange things with their bodies. Lecter leads Clarise on a maze with his word and mind games to gain more information, when suddenly, Katherine Martin, Senator Ruth Martin's daughter, is kidnapped by Buffalo Bill. Now Clarise must use Lecter as her main resource to find Buffalo Bill so Katherine Martin can be safely rescued in this race of time.  This is my favorite movie, and everything about it is absolutley amazing! Jodie Foster's award winning performance is stunning, as it that of Anthony Hopkins, who is more than terrifying. It's a classic movie in my book.  END

Jody Foster plays an FBI recruit who has a knack for solving difficult problems and situations. She is mentored by Agent Crawford and asked to assist on a serial killer case. This leads her to meeting Hannibal Lector (Played In Previous Film By Brian Cox) played by Anthony Hopkins in his Academy Award winning role. Foster's character, Clarice Starling grew up lower middle class and Lector is able to detect this once the two converse. Starling disobeys orders and tells Lector all about herself in a "quid pro quo" arrangement so Lector can assist in nabbing the killer who soon kidnaps another girl.

I won't go into too many more details as others have done that better than I could. I liked this film as pure drama but I feel it was a bit too dark and garish for my tastes. Too, why would Buffalo Bill toy with Agent Starling when he could have killed her. With his night vision goggles he could see that she was armed and ready to fire. Thus he would not have cocked his pistol in her presence (He Had Plenty Of Time To Do That Earlier) because she would have heard it and slain him as she did. That was contrived. Perhaps it was in the book. I don't know. But if that's the case then the scene in the book was also contrived.

I give this film Three and a Half Stars. You might like it if you buy It on DVD. I'm the 1910 person to review this film. I saw it from an old tape I made from cable.

The Silence of the Lambs is one of the most iconic horror movies despite "normals" trying to separate it from the genre. Well kiddos, a movie with a serial killer trying to make a human skin suit definitely qualifies as a horror movie... DEAL WITH IT! :D

Moving on - The Silence of the Lambs is an all-around great piece of cinema. Foster's accent isn't completely golden but her acting is along with everyone else in the film. There's not a lot of action but when the film kicks it up a notch, it does things right. And although you can't see all the kills, there is quality gore for us "everyday" horror fans.

The Silence of the Lambs was a fantastically well-done movie. There was a redundant shot I felt they overused, but it was done well too, just got a bit annoyed with it. Center screen close-ups, The actor would be looking into the camera as well. It was real cool at first, but that got overused. Perfect movie nonetheless. No jump scares, yet extremely suspenseful, and kept me leaning towards the screen wondering what's about to happen. The foreshadowing is just spectacular as well. They don't show any gratuitous gore, but they don't show it very cleverly, even though you know it's happening. Even when Hannibal escapes, it's brutal, but they show minimal, with great effect. The dead bodies were gross, but it wasn't shown when it was done, only talked about how it was done. Kinda like Bones in a way. I'm super happy I watched that. they should've related it to how moths are attracted to light unless we're supposed to realize that ourselves. The three main actors, being Hannibal, Buffalo Bill, and Starling were all just great. Everyone else was believable as well, but they stole the entire movie. Especially Hannibal. This movie is stupendous. Go watch it if you haven't yet. Just perfect.

What can be said that hasn't been already? Though this movie often gets labeled a "psychological thriller" to reconcile its Oscar wins, this is as true a horror film as you can watch--it's truly, genuinely horrifying. The grotesque artistry these serial killers display is undeniably unsettling, but the emphasis on close-up shots, on facial recognition of the terror at hand, gives the proceedings a very personal sense of terror. You'll come watch for Anthony Hopkins' legendary turn as one of cinema's most iconic, imitated villains, but you'll stay for Jodie Foster's underappreciated work as Clarice--this is the sort of sensitive but steely, energetic but nuanced movie-star performance you only hear about in fairy tales.

And I will submit Buffalo Bill walking toward the camera with night goggles as one of the single most frightening images ever to be ingrained in my subconscious. That this recurring shot is part of a flawlessly enthralling third act is icing on the cake.

See it if you haven't, see it again if you have.

There is a musical adaptation of the movie called Silence! The Musical. It is just as clever and raunchy as the movie, and funny in parts. It's been shown in London, New York, Chicago and L. A. Showing in San Francisco at the end of January, 2017. Go see it if you have the chance, but make sure you've seen the movie and like the movie before seeing the musical. If you like the movie, you'll love the musical.

Silence of the Lambs is possibly the best psychological thriller of all time. It crosses a few genres including horror at times and it really does keep the audience on the edge of their seats for the entire run time of the film. Just based on how many films and television shows have copied or imitated the style and story structure of this film proves how revolutionary it really is. Nothing is going to emulate the performance of Anthony Hopkins though. Jodie Foster is great, but Hopkins steals every scene that he's in. It's awe inspiring acting. As far as the production, everything is pretty much perfect from the story to the direction, editing, score, etc... It's easily one of my favorite films.

The Silence of the Lambs is a slow-burning suspense thriller with a multi-layered psychological horror plot. I *never* give five stars except for classics, but this film has held up over the years and has become a true classic, in my opinion. Yes, it has some disturbingly violent scenes and it deals with some of the dregs of humanity. And yet, by shining the light in those dark corners where the human cockroaches live, it shows us what it can mean to be human if we are not afforded a decent upbringing or help when mental health issues *begin*, rather than when they get out of hand. It also raises the question of whether some people are just born evil and are beyond redemption.

Juxtaposed against the worst of humanity is Jodie Foster as the fresh-faced, hyperintelligent yet somehow innocent FBI agent, who can look at the worst that one human being can do to another and still continue her mission to find and stop the perpetrator. Add Scott Glenn as her world-weary yet still optimistic mentor and you have a team that got their man, even if other forces let another evil slip through their fingers.

I've lost count of how many times I've seen this movie. Somehow, I never grow tired of it. Whenever I am flipping through channels on TV and I find it, I will start watching it wherever it happens to be at the moment, even if it is in the middle or near the end. With most movies I *have* to watch them from the beginning but I know this one so well I don't need to fill in the blanks. Sometimes it concerns me that I am so fascinated by such a dark movie about extremely disturbed characters, but I have always been fascinated by the workings of the human mind. This represents, for the most part, one end of the spectrum, with Clarice Starling's character as the opposite end. Good against evil - a tale as old as humanity. It's no wonder so many people find this fascinating.

After all these years it's still as good as the first time I saw it. It is not only exciting but instructive. Clarice is kind of my avatar--I learn how human psychology and pathology work while she goes through the motions. The characters are both brilliantly conceived and superbly performed.

The two contrasting traits of Hannibal Lechter, brilliance bordering clairvoyance and cannibalism, make him a fascinating character to watch. And his protagonist, the unthreatening, plain, innocent FBI trainee Clarice Starling, provides even more contrast. Hannibal exposes human traits as he heals Clarice from a childhood trauma and avenges her violated honor by persuading a fellow inmate to kill himself by swallowing his own tongue. The staggering suspense and fears for the victim Buffalo Bill holds in a shaft of his house culminate in Clarice's shootout with Buffalo Bill.

This is about as perfect as a movie can get; Silence of the Lambs (1991) is a psychological horror/thriller movie that has all the elements of greatness: the right setting (outer city neighborhoods) at the right time of the year (autumn), thrills, hair-raising suspense, great acting, great directing, great plot, great script, character development, etc. This is one of those movies that draws in the viewer, and when done watching it, begs to be seen again right away (sort of like loving a certain roller coaster, and wanting to ride it again right away). Anthony Hopkins gives a chilling and unbelievable performance as Hannibal Lecter, a scary figure with incredible wit and an elusiveness that makes his character that much scarier. Jody Foster shines as the heroine Clarice Starling, an FBI apprentice who embarks upon the case of a lifetime, and succeeds. Both Foster and Hopkins are stellar, and elevate the film to a higher level of expectation and entertainment. The music is very well done, and really illustrates the darkness and cold world of Hannibal, as well as Clarice. The Silence of the Lambs is essential to anyone's movie collection, as it has tremendous replay value. The special features are very good, and are a great bonus to this iconic movie.

Jodie Foster plays an FBI Agent named Clarice Starling, who is given the task to talk to Dr. Lecter and seek his help on capturing a serial killer named Buffalo Bill. The superbly crafted suspense thriller that director Jonathan Demme has made from Thomas Harris's taut best-selling novel The Silence of the Lambs slams you like a sudden blast of bone-chilling, pulse-pounding terror. Clarice Starling, played with heartfelt tenacity by Jodie Foster, is an FBI trainee on the trail of a serial killer. Her search ends in the suburban home of dressmaker Jame Gumb (Ted Levine). It is Gumb's cellar workshop  the place where he shoots and skins his tall, fleshy female victims  that Demme transforms into a harrowing vision of hell.

By putting the focus on the Doctor's eyes, the viewer cannot help but be sucked into the film and join in the hunt for Buffalo Bill (played very very well by a pre-"Monk" Ted Levine) . Definitely deserved  all the awards that it received.

Silence of the Lambs (1991) follows the story of the young and ambitious Clarice Starling in her attempt to apprehend the serial killer named Buffalo Bill (Ted Levine). Starling goes to the infamous Hannibal Lecter (nicknamed Hannibal the Cannibal for his exotic tastes). Clarice relies on Lecter for his expertise and knowledge about the mind of a serial killer. Whereas Hannibal toys with Clarice in order to amuse himself. Clarice and her fellow agents are forced to rely on the help of a killer in order to catch another.
 Jodie Foster does an excellent job playing the young and eager Clarice. She portrays her Southern accent as often painfully obvious, which Lecter pounces upon as an insecurity. Foster speaks with a wavering voice at times, showing Clarices inexperience and disgust with the crimes committed by Buffalo Bill. Hopkins is completely absorbed into the role of Hannibal Lecter. To create his creepy and psychotic persona he stares unblinkingly, forcing both the audience and Clarice to return his cold gaze. Hopkins keeps as still as possible while acting, looking like a snake poised to pounce upon less intelligent prey, and in comparison to Lecter everyone is less intelligent, and is therefore potential prey. Hopkins keeps a soft smirk on his lips throughout the film as if to say he knows something no one else does.
The films soundtrack is absolutely haunting and mysterious. It works well with the film to create tension and anxiety in the audience. However, the director (Jonathan Demme) knows when silence is just as powerful. In a tense scene in complete darkness we are left with no sound save for the heavy breathing of Buffalo Bill. The cinematography is excellent for this film. The colors of the film are gray and lifeless, which complement the films dark subject matter. At pivotal moments the camera angle switches to first person. This view works perfectly when Clarice rounds the corner and sees Lecter for the first time. We are able to truly appreciate Lecters piercing gaze, because we see it first hand through Clarices eyes.
The performances of Hopkins and Foster would have been flat if it were not for the well written script. The small anecdotal stories about Lecter help to build his character even before we meet him.  Lecters lines are meant to sound sophisticated and cultured in order to create his paradoxical character as a gentleman-psychopath. Buffalo Bill refers to his victims as it in an attempt to destroy their humanity in another example of brilliant writing.
 A key strength in this film is its character development. Not just Lecter or Clarices development, but their relationship itself. The audience watches as Lecter and Clarice grow closer and closer in a bizarre exchange not unlike two friends sharing secrets. As Clarice learns more from Lecter, so too does Lecter learn more about Clarice. The audience can see that Lecter values this relationship because he does not hunt her down for as Clarice puts it, He would consider that rude.
 Silence of the Lambs is a gripping and disturbing film, filled with fascinating characters. It remains a timeless horror film that draws from the darkest and foulest corner of humanitys existence. It is a terrifying movie because it reminds us that the monsters in our world are not imaginary, but could pass us on the street any day.

Yesterday, February 14, 2016, marked the 25th anniversary of the release of The Silence of the Lambs, one of the greatest crime thriller movies of all time. Its an odd date for a movie release to be sure, but it certainly didn't hurt this film either at the box office ($131 million) or at the Academy Awards. Its one of only a handful of movies to sweep Oscars in all five top categories: Best Picture, Best Actor (Anthony Hopkins), Best Actress (Jodie Foster), Best Director (Jonathan Demme), and Best Writing-Adapted Material (Ted Tally).

The FBIs top criminal profiler, Jack Crawford,  assigns a young agent trainee named Clarice Starling (Foster) to conduct a routine field interview with the infamous Hannibal Lechter, a serial killer notorious for dismembering and eating his victims  hence earning the nickname Hannibal the Cannibal. Crawford (played by Scott Glenn) hopes that Lechter (Hopkins) can give insight into the motivations behind a new series of grisly murders being committed by a psychopathic killer known only as Buffalo Bill.

During the interview, which is conducted in the maximum security psychiatric prison where Lechter is held, Hannibal the Cannibal uses his twisted intellect to get into Clarices mind and under her skin, thereby creating within her doubts about herself and her ability to help find and capture Buffalo Bill. But Lechter has a much larger and more sinister agenda in mind, and he plans on using Clarice as a means to achieving his ultimately horrific goals

The Silence of the Lambs is a terrific film in nearly every respect. It is, in equal parts, a psychological thriller, police procedural, and horror film. Each part is magnificently brought to the screen.  Foster is superb as the up-and-coming FBI agent, who is, at the same time, ambitious, superbly competent, and keenly intellectual. Hopkins is deliciously malevolent as the evil, wily Hannibal Lechter.  The film is tightly woven, suspenseful, thoroughly engrossing, and abounding with enough plot twists to keep viewers guessing for the films entire two-hour runtime.

Ive watched The Silence of the Lambs many times over the past 25 years, and every time Ive found myself sitting on the edge of my seat in fascination as Clarice and her FBI colleagues face off with Hannibal Lechter, while seeking to bring Buffalo Bill to justice. Most highly recommended.

The Silence of the Lambs, 1991 film

A new FBI employee is given an assignment: to interview a mad serial killer. [Was this payback for her earlier questioning of Jack Crawford at her college?] Clarissa Starling visits Hannibal Lecter in the Baltimore State Hospital for the Criminally Insane, and converses with him. She deciphers his cryptic advice "look inside yourself", visits the storage facility that Hannibal rented, and finds a body part. In another scene the film shows how a killer takes advantage of a woman's help to a stranger. [Isn't this after dark activity a little bit suspicious?] When her body is examined in the funeral parlor it becomes a case for the state pathologist. [Did that Sheriff really need those six Deputies there?] They find a cocoon inside the body, a rare species that will leave a paper trail. [Are state entomologists that buggy?]

Clarisse makes Hannibal an offer to get his help. When this is revealed as a scam (by the prison psychologist!) the scandal results in Hannibal's transfer to a Memphis prison. [Can you believe this?] Next the story shows Hannibal cleverly escaping from his cage. Could those police be so easily fooled? Clarisse drives to Belvedere Ohio to investigate the background of the first victim. [Don't the FBI travel in pairs?] Clarisse follows the trail to the sewing lady, Mrs. Lipman. She talks to a suspicious person. [Why didn't she call for backup?] This action keeps your attention!

This horror film has a slight redeeming value. It warns against making assumptions about strangers, no matter how innocuous they may appear. But I can't believe the local police could have overlooked that suspect. This film implicitly argues that serial killers should be executed, no good comes from keeping them alive for study. This film mocks the people in it. The experienced profiler follows a false clue to an empty house, the rookie finds the killer with basic police work (questioning all the associates of the victim). At the end (in Haiti?) it implies there will be a sequel. The killer in this film seems to have copied the modus operandi of some real serial killers. Serial killers are always sane because they know the difference between right and wrong. Their efforts to conceal their crime says so. ["Hannibal Lecter" seems to be loosely based on Ted Bundy.]

Johnathon Demmes The Silence of the Lambs (1991) is perhaps an anomalyits not your average slasher horror film or predictable thriller, which have come to dominant the genre.  The haunting performances and psychological interaction between the characters, coupled with the presence of a strong female character, makes for an eerie production that brings raw emotion into the thriller genre.

Based off the book by the same name, The Silence of the Lambs depicts the strange and emotional relationship between FBI trainee Clarice Starling (Jodie Foster) and cannibalistic serial-killer Dr. Hannibal Lector (Anthony Hopkins). Clarice is sent by FBI agent Jack Crawford (Scott Glenn) to consult with Dr. Lector about Buffalo Bill (Ted Levine), an illusive serial-killer running rampant throughout the US.  However, she must open up to the sadistic killer in order to gain his trust.

The plot is undoubtedly intense and well-written.  However, its not so much the storyline as the performances of the actors that make Silence a must-see.  Hopkins control and almost monotone high-pitched voice takes sadistic lines to a whole new level.  His gaze brought shivers down my spine as he delves into Clarices psyche.  But Clarice can hold her own against the former psychiatrist.  Foster plays her character as young and innocent, but not to a fault.  She uses Clarices naivety and lack of experience as an advantage to stand up to Lector, which he, in turn, finds admirable.

In a way, there are two antagonists of this film, and one of them surprisingly isn't Hannibal Lector.  The FBI not only has to fight against Buffalo Bill, but Clarice has to battle a chauvinistic society.  Being one of the only females in a male dominated field, she doesnt get the same respect as some of the others.  However, Silence does an excellent job of portraying Fosters character as confident and strongand even more cunning than the veterans of the FBI.  A strong female presence not only adds to the storyline, but is also the crucial element in the relationship between Dr. Lector and Clarice.  Though a sick man at heart, Dr. Lector recognizes the corruption in the system, and protects Clarice.  They form a bond that is not often shown in horror movies.  Though their only interaction is through Clarices interviews, this makes their conversations that much more intense and emotional.

While the emotional connection is the focal point of the film, the climax of the movie is not to be forgotten either.  Its suspenseful, quite creepy, and adds a string of scenes that even avid horror fans will find unnerving.  Enhancing the climax is the score created by Howard Shore.  Some thrillers give away the pivotal moments with obnoxious music, but I found that Silences soundtrack actually aided the development of the climax.  Rather than being loud and boisterous, its subtlety makes it evermore creepy, and still haunting to this day.

The Silence of the Lambs is well-deserving of its five Academy Awards awards, but those awards don't define the filmrather its boldness makes this movie a classic.  Demme isn't afraid to address topics such as transgenderism and feminism.  He doesnt shy away from giving Lector human emotions.  And call me crazy, but he almost makes me root for a cannibalistic serial killer.
it is a good quality scary movie, I enjoy putting it one every once in a while,  and I like Anthony Hopkins

The Silence of the Lambs, based on the Thomas Harris book of the same name, is one of the most disturbing films based on fictional material to win the Academy Award for Best Picture, Best Actor, Best Actress, and Best Director. When you consider that films like "My Fair Lady", "the Sound of Music", "Driving Miss Daisy", "Rain Man", and "Forrest Gump" have also earned the Best Picture prize, Lambs sort of stands alone. Best Picture Films which match Lambs on the disturbing meter are predominantly set in historical situations, such as Platoon, Gandhi, the Hurt Locker and Schindler's List. Possibly the only other fictional Best Picture winners which could compete with the horror of Lambs is "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" and "Unforgiven". But none of these movies ever dealt with not one but two serial-killer sociopaths in a suburban-rural setting.

Despite the outstanding quality of this horror-suspense film, "Lambs" is not for the feint of heart. "Lambs" centers around three characters dealing with intense psychological dysfunction. Each character in turn not only reacts to their dysfunction in their own style but each is in very different circumstances. Two of the three engage in horrific behavior of extreme violence, succumbing to the darkest side of human behavior as a result of their mental illness and dysfunctional pathology. At the story's beginning, one of them is in an institution for the criminally insane, having had a history of violent and sadistic behavior. The second is on the loose, dispatching young women for reasons yet unknown. The third character deals with her psychological issues by joining the FBI, and her reason d'etre becomes a mission to stop violent behavior and rescue potential victims at the hands of sociopaths.

If a "story" is about the growth and change of a character, then Lambs' narrative is really about Clarice Starling, an FBI trainee who is majoring in the Behavioral Science division which does psychological profiling of criminals, particularly serial killers. Her first real task, or test in a sense, is to psychologically profile the serial killer Hannibal Lecter, nicknamed "the Cannibal", played with such a believable yet sadistic sensibility by Anthony Hopkins that make Dracula and Frankenstein's monster seem more like Saturday morning cartoon villains by comparison. Lecter is possibly one of the most fascinating and simultaneously repulsive characters in fiction and film. He is a fusion of an Ivy League liberal arts professor who easily quotes ancient philosophers and the Monster of Venice, an Italian serial killer who dispatched victims, usually women, without a shred of empathy. But Lecter also has a fondness for high culture, displayed by his drawing of the Duomo in Milan. Italy.

We learn Lecter had been a university professor of psychology who made it a habit of eating human victims. At story's beginning, he resides at a prison of mentally disturbed criminals where Starling first meets him in person. Starling and Lecter form a strange yet compelling bond, not quite true friendship but something more meaningful than mere acquaintance. Part of the story is the evolution of Starling's and Lecter's relationship. A very subtle undertone of sexual flirting is hinted at in some scenes and yet we know that these two worlds could never permanently mesh.

Eventually, Starling begins to solicit the help of Lecter to arrest the perpetrator of the horrid acts of the second character. At film's beginning, we learn the FBI is hot on the trail of a strange woman-killer, nicknamed Buffalo Bill by the press. Buffalo Bill has dispatched five women, but no one at the agency can figure out his motive. With Lecter's help, Starling begins to unravel who Buffalo Bill is from a psychological standpoint as a means of finding out his identity and where he lives. Part of the narrative involves the revealing of both Starling and her target Buffalo Bill, although the most interesting and colorful character, Hannibal Lecter, remains completely enigmatic. The story then pushes into a new direction when a young woman from a prominent family is kidnapped and it is believed she has been abducted by Buffalo Bill. Can Starling extract enough information from Lecter to save the young woman before Buffalo Bill dispatches another innocent victim?

One of the first elements that strikes you about Lambs is its foreboding atmosphere with some scenes having a quasi-medieval flavor. When Starling first visits the corridor inside the mental prison which houses Lecter, you feel like you're walking into a medieval dungeon. The stone brick is dirty and damp, and the inmates seem like something right out of Dante's Inferno (Hell). The same is true for Buffalo Bill's hideout, a maze of dark corridors filled with strange objects, like mannequins and costumes. The place where he imprisons his victims rings of something out of the Spanish Inquisition. Themes of raw sexuality permeate the entire story, although there is no love affair between any of the characters. Simultaneously, there are also overtones of objectifying human beings. Dr Chilton, the doctor in charge of Lecter at the hospital, boasts of having his sociopath patient, "So rare to capture one alive. From a research point of view, Lecter is our most prized asset," as if Lecter is a rare object rather than a person. Also, the serial killers objectify their victims as a means of rationalizing their behavior.

"The Silence of the Lambs" is one of the best horror-suspense films of its type with absolutely first-rate acting by the leads and the supports. And one of the most disturbing. But if you're looking for escapist innocent fun, Lambs will have you running under the covers, or at least switching to "My Fair Lady". Lecter and Buffalo Bill are the stuff nightmares are made of.

What more can be said about this movie? It's a classic crime thriller, suspense drama, horror movie; it wears as many hats as Hannibal himself. Its first charm is the underdog protagonist, Clarice Starling, played expertly by Jodie Foster. Clarice must do all she can to overcome a lower-class childhood that was cut short by her father's tragic death. The sympathetic hero is opposed by a multitude of villainous characters, not the least of which are supposed to be on her own side. Aside from the hideous Dr. Chilton and her job's bureaucratic gloryhounds, Clarice must also deal with psychotic murderers Hannibal Lecter and Jame Gumb. The only ones on her side are boss Jack Crawford, who often finds his own hands tied by the job, and her roommate, the benign Ardelia Mapp. In battling the inner and outer forces that hold her back, Clarice fights the good fight, and all of us who have our own disadvantages to conquer cheer her on. Representing the opposite of her extreme need for order are the chaotic figures of Lecter and Gumb, the former civilized, sophisticated, and incarcerated, the latter reckless, flamboyant, and all too free. Anthony Hopkins applied his stage discipline to the role of Lecter and created a household name. Hannibal is one of the most popular of all movie villains, right up there with Jason Voorhees, Freddy Krueger, and Leatherface.  The voice and body movements Hopkins used to transform into the monster are on par with anything Lugosi or Karloff ever pulled off. Besides the fact that this movie intertwines the heroes and villains in a highly suspenseful police procedural format, the twist ending, achieved with seamless simultaneous editing, completes the package and elevates Silence of the Lambs to the level of true classic. Incredible story, amazing acting, and expert directing; you can't ask for more than that.

Anthony Hopkins's performance as a genteel sort of cannibal serial killer is exquisite, and Jodie Foster walks a fine line between being extra vulnerable due to her gender and showing her strength while overcoming obstacles as a woman in a man's job.

I really enjoyed that the two main characters had depth to them - neither was a perfect angel or a perfect monster.  This is definitely more sophisticated than your average horror movie, but still very scary.  The person next to me was so scared that he was gripping me for moral support, and I won't lie - my heart was racing at several points.  Even though I had seen it before and knew how it all turned out, I was still terrified for the characters!

The Silence of the Lambs is one of the coolest action suspense movies EVER!!!! This is really a classic with superb acting from Anthony Hopkins and Jodie Foster!!!! The story is brutal, dark but brilliant!!!!Hugely recommended!!!Masterpiece!

SILENCE OF THE LAMBS is a mesmerizing tale of the most heinous of nightmares come true as FBI agent Clarice (Jodie Foster) is immersed into an abyss of the darkest side of deviant human behavior where the flesh eating Dr. Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins) agrees to assist her in her investigation to capture a serial killer who commits unspeakable atrocities on his victims. Jodie Foster must traverse into a world of dark sickening debauchery to capture the killer. The story takes several turns heightening the intensity and unspeakable terror of her assignment. The story is unsettling in its own right but the film seen from Foster's perspective has a pervasive feel of paranoia as if she has not been given all the information she needs or even further to suggest she is actually being set up as bait. One scene in particular comes to mind when sitting in the back seat of the car her boss (Scott Glenn) speaks cryptically to her and she just gazes at the back of his head once he turns around. You really don't know what either character is thinking. Very disturbing.

At no time do you see any "contact" gore, it's all implied and you have to use your imagination (even though it still grips you).

Jodi Foster plays the role of Agent Clarice Starling and as being placed on top of her class for her impressive grades, she is chosen to go on a mission to help stop a psychopath from killing more women, and to save the life of one who is held captive. Her mission involves an interview with a demented prisoner, who may be able to give her clues to the killer's next move. Anthony Hopkins plays the role of the prisoner, a psychiatrist, who is mentally ill, and extremely dangerous.

Clarice is fore-warned before interviewing the prisoner, to not allow him to get inside her head, which was an impossible task. The prisoner bargains with her to help her follow the footsteps of Buffalo Bill, as long as she conveys a dark secret about her past. She agrees, but isn't sure if she would be strong and stable enough to fulfill her mission of finding Buffalo Bill, and saving the life of his most recent kidnapping.

The chilling story becomes edge-of-your-seat suspense, and the ending is as frightening as the beginning as you follow the actions of the prisoner's scary intentions. Jodi Foster and Anthony Hopkins give Outstanding Acting Performances, and this movie is packed with thrills-and-chills throughout. Highly recommended for thriller lovers, who enjoy mystery with intense suspense!

If you haven't seen this movie, the basic premise is that Jodie Foster is a young F.B.I. agent on the hunt for a serial killer.  Cue in Hannibal Lector, a cannibalistic genius who provides Fosters character with clues and insight into how to find the elusive killer.  Overall, its an extremely entertaining movie that Ive seen at least four or five times.  It never seems to get old.  Probably still my favorite of the franchise.  It is definitely a must see film.

It is a perfect example of mastery and expressiveness in a commercial film. Hopkins' meticulously contained representation of unrestrained pathology is horrifying. But the way Jonathon Demme's camera lets us longer in close-up on Jodie Foster's face, so patient and receptive to our attention, gives this film is spine and it's haunting afterlife.

Jonathan Demme was in a unique position when he made this quasi-art film back in 1991. A director more accustomed to comedies and "normal" mainstream projects, he was probably not the first choice to guide the reins of this out-of-control monster movie (but, as it turned out, he was the best choice). Sometimes, placing a horror film director behind the scenes of a straight drama film can work wonders, and occasionally putting a musical director behind the chariot of a blockbuster thriller can provide small miracles. It's a matter of reconstituting the elements in a different frame. Sometimes, the layered skills of a director can provide the same decent palette strokes upon a previously non-traversed canvas as it can upon familiar stomping grounds, but often this will produce more effective results. Move the mind of a musical adapter into the playing field of a horror story and you may get something spectacular as a result. "The Silence of the Lambs," as a result, almost gets there.
The most obvious thing to say is that Jodie Foster is both desirable and stirring in her role; she has never been better, or more attractive (at least not in my opinion). Anthony Hopkins, however, takes a previously literary character and moves his ghostly mind play into an empirical creation that would have worked better from the shadows than with definable features but, nonetheless, here we go again. Critic Gene Siskel attacked this one because of its gruesome subject matter, and, more importantly to relate, "The Silence of the Lambs" does not have much to offer on the visual side of things (other than the radiant Foster), as its bleak, distressing, and bloody canvas becomes a bit too much to take at times. The purpose of Demme's film was to transfer the big ugly monster that is serial killers on the loose in modern society into the mindset of a mainstream Hollywood thriller script, and lure audiences into the debate by using hyper-violent and sensationalized characterizations to overstress the point. What history will make of a film that tries to build the anxiety of modern living by introducing fear of the unknown person (those hidden individual killers amongst us) is quite difficult to assess at this point. In the age of increasing technology and social media, the job of the serial killer is now (thankfully) more difficult in modern society, but there's also something human that we are going to lose by giving up so much of our privacy and our renegade sensibilities. Rather than questioning this aspect of modern police work and FBI tampering with the lives of citizens, "The Silence of the Lambs" ends up being about the unreliable aspects of basic thriller filmmaking. It really doesn't have much to do with reality, and this aspect is very disturbing to me (as a critic). Serial killers had become the new vampires and werewolves back in 1991, and this film goes towards that sensibility with full-steam ahead. I also did not care for the Buffalo Bill character. Demme did a great job in building the tension--and there are certain aspects of its mystery genre writing that make the film fascinating in some of its minutia (I love the insect studies angle, for example)--but overall this is a softened version of what a great serial killer portrait should be, meaning that it is manipulative, loaded, and too interested in becoming a horror film effort that it fails to gain its sense of verisimilitude once it decides to move beyond the bounds of reality (starting with Hannibal's escape from prison, one of the more ludicrous "c'mon audience, accept it now" moments in the film). I have not witnessed this one proper in a theater setting yet, so maybe I'm being a bit harsh, but overall the effort is quite mediocre. However, there are enjoyable moments--not the content, but in the pacing, the scares, and the music (by "The Fly" composer Howard Shore, of all people). It might be a female empowerment movie, but it's not the best showcase for that idea even.
The BluRay is nice--although the extras take the study of serial killers a little bit more seriously than this entertainment vehicle is capable of competing with (these FBI tidbits are more disturbing than the actual movie). The "From Page to Screen" documentary is an essential item, however, discussing the source text of author Thomas Harris (a wise, elusive literary figure), and how the disturbing novel was translated to the more dubious idiom of film. To me, though, the most powerful supplement on the BluRay is the deleted scenes. Watch these if you decide to purchase this title. The inclusion of these deleted moments made me question as to whether or not the movie might have been stronger had these been left in. Definitely a must-see. The DVD included is rather pointless though, because it is basically a copy of the movie without the extras (something that a great company like Shout! Factory would never permit in their detail-precise endeavors). So, overall, if you want a good mystery story, this is by no means a terrible movie, but it was a way too overly hyped movie for its time. However, it might stand up better in future, who knows? To me, there is a certain nostalgic value to it, and I enjoy it on that FBI/cop movie-thriller level--it's as good as one that you'll find from the 90's.  AND, finally, as one other note, I don't agree with Siskel that we have to censor such movies as this one. What we need to teach in society is self-control, not cultural control. Once the lunacy of the moral crusades of the Christian right and conservatives starts to make film goers feel guilty again, we are in danger of losing the point of cinema in the first place (which is to express cathartic dreams, not to try and compete with reality). America is about freedom (or, at least, it is supposed to be), and we can't place restrictions upon our art. If we take away expressions of our darkest dreams and nightmares (from fantasy revenge violence to pornographic imagery to controversial themes such as cancer in the young), then what are we really doing as humans? It is possible to defend this film and not just attack it because of its tasteless subject matter. But I wouldn't label it a classic just yet. C+

Considering the notoriety of the film I decided to forgo my usual in-depth review and merely comment on the film as an experience.

Watching "Silence of the Lambs" last night I was struck by how powerful it is in spite of the many times I have seen it. My heart races more during the final face to face between Lecter and Starling than any violent scene in any modern "horror" movie. This is true suspense film making of the highest level. Every performance is excellent and directorial decisions that would sound disastrous when talked about work so well that you never even think about them until you really examine the film objectively. Even the simplest of scenes strike such emotional responses. Terror, disgust, fear, empathy, awkwardness, triumph, regret. If you can handle the subject matter and disturbing imagery and you haven't seen it yet, then do so. Ignore all of the sequels, this is the one.

This marks the third time I've seen this movie, and again, it's terrifying as we enter the mind of two killers. Hannibal Lecter, brilliant psychoanalyst, is able to help Agent Clarice Starling, a young woman haunted by an incident in her earlier life. I won't reveal it for others who haven't seen this brilliantly directed movie. Jody Foster is marvelous as Clarice. Normally I am not a fan of the "killer thrillers", but I'm very willing to make an exception in this case.  I will do that for one simple reason...his movie has a plot and it's a good one.  Anthony Hopkins may only be in the film for about twelve or so minutes but he radiates such madness and danger that his presence is felt even if he wasn't on the set when a particular scene was being filmed.  Dr. Hannibal Lector is certainly a villain worth remembering.  Jody Foster is his equal in FBI trainee Clarice Starling as she does her best to not get sucked into the doctor's sickening mind games while attempting to create some of her own.  Scott Glen portrays Jack Crawford, Starling's superior whose weariness can be sensed with every word and motion as he does whatever he can to hunt down the vicious serial killer "Buffalo Bill".  And speaking of Billy, Ted Lavene is a great addition to the cast and one can only wonder how much he was paid to act so disturbed (I couldn't come up with a performance like that on my best day.)  The actors all did their homework on serial killers and the people who strive to catch them and that effort paid off.  Under the helm of director Jonathan Demme, this film earned every one of the "Top 5" Oscars that it got.  It's a must-have for anyone who likes a good crime thriller.  And remember...it's not your standard slasher film...never saw any of those get the "Top 5" Oscars.

This is a mesmerizing tale of the most heinous of nightmares come true as FBI agent Clarice (Jodie Foster) is immersed into an abyss of the darkest side of deviant human behavior where the flesh eating Dr. Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins) agrees to assist her in her investigation to capture a serial killer who commits unspeakable atrocities on his victims. Jodie Foster must traverse into a world of dark sickening debauchery to capture the killer. The story takes several turns heightening the intensity and unspeakable terror of her assignment. The story is unsettling in its own right but the film seen from Foster's perspective has a pervasive feel of paranoia as if she has not been given all the information she needs or even further to suggest she is actually being set up as bait. One scene in particular comes to mind when sitting in the back seat of the car her boss (Scott Glenn) speaks cryptically to her and she just gazes at the back of his head once he turns around. You really don't know what either character is thinking. Very disturbing.

The first time I watched this movie, I was between 15 and 17 years old. At the time, I couldn't understand why it wasn't trashed. 5 oscars for this kind of movie, that's insane! Was my original opinion. Then I watched it a few more times with an open-mind. Jodie Foster, Scott Glenn and of course Anthony Hopkins, all played their parts brilliantly. Then there's Anthony Heald, who played the annoyingly flirtatious Dr. Chilton, and Ted Levine as Buffalo Bill, was excessively creepy in many ways. What baffles me about this film now though, is why the gay-community was so angry over the praise it received. Now, granted, I'm part of that community myself, the difference is, I try to be fairly analytical in most cases, even with movies. Point 1: buffalo bill was not a transsexual,a closeted homosexual or even transgendered. Point 2, Dr. Lecter's profile on buffalo bill seemed pretty clear-cut for me, I feel like I was the only gay/bi-sexual person paying attention at the time, am I wrong? And finally point 3, Jeff Dahmer's killings weren't revealed until two years after this film was released. Director Jonathan Demme also made Philadelphia in 1993, to point out the problems with homophobia, to me, the gay-community didn't see the whole movie or cheery-picked the parts they didn't like to make their case. On a different note, I still say Eminem was sucking up to the gay-community by performing with Elton John, but that's a debate for another time. Final note: Silence of the Lambs, creepy, atmospheric, but emmensely effective, and obviously not for everyone.

Silence of the lambs is truly a remarkable achievement. One of only a small handfull of psychological horror films to truly deserve a best picture academy award for 1991. Jodie Foster makes a striking comeback as the emotionally uneven yet determined FBI agent, Starling. It is interesting to note that Silence of the lambs is probably the best remake of any film ever made. In the early 80's Michael Mann directed the original based on the same novel. In that version William Peterson took the title role of a similarly fragile FBI agent unsure of his own sanity. Mann's film was really very good, and the villian of that one was not Hannibal Lector though the character appears in the film. The serial killer portrayed in that film had Tom Noonan in the role of the murderer known as the 'Tooth Ferry'. And again it was a much better film than the boxoffice receipts really indicated. Silence of the Lambs still proved to be a much better film, so that is saying a lot. Of course Sir Anthony Hopkins created a truly terrifying character in Lecter, and it won him a much deserved best actor oscar. Hopkins is truly astonishing playing Lector. Jonathan Demme directs this film with heart pounding realism and a slick pace. Ted Levine is in top form as the killer on the loose. Interesting as well is how Levine managed to break free of of being type cast after this movie. He went on to play good guys mostly, usually cops over the past 18 years since. In this version of the book Starling must follow the trail of the killer with the help of Lector and her superior played by Scott Glen. Foster also delivers an academy award winning performance, and Silence of the lambs remains one of the greatest thrillers ever made.
Taut, well written and beautifully acted, this in my view is one of the all time great movie classics. A must see.

Starring Jodie Foster and Anthony Hopkins in two memorable performances, the film opens with a young FBI agent in training, Clarice Starling (Foster). A serial killer nicknamed Buffalo Bill is on the loose and Starling is given the assignment of talking to the incarcerated Hannibal Lecter (Hopkins). He formally was a brilliant psychiatrist and he turned into a cannibalistic killer. Lecter gives Starling hints on how to find the killer but not without forcing her to open up about her past. She closes in on the murderer and after some tense moments she finishes the job a hero. Now a certified FBI agent, Starling gets a call from Lecter who had escaped previously. He bids her farewell as chilling as ever and this time he is a free man. The acting was good and there were definitely some great thrills.

** This review contains spoilers. **

Clarice Starling works very hard and is regarded as an exceptional student at the FBI Academy. Jack Crawford, her mentor and teacher, enlists her help to present a questionnaire to Dr. Hannibal Lecter, a brilliant but deranged psychologist infamous for cannibalism, manipulation, and murder. He scoffs at her attempts and sees that her mentor actually wants his help in the current serial killer case, where the murderer known as Buffalo Bill skins women. After a disgusting act from another inmate, Lecter decides to help her by giving her a riddle to solve. This marks the start of their odd relationship where he provides information and insight in return for details on her personal life. Clarice will face her own personal demons as well as a deranged killer before she has even become a full fledged FBI agent.

Clarice Starling is one of my favorite horror heroines. She's focused, dedicated, and strong, but many around her don't see her this way. Upon my latest viewing, I noticed that Clarice is very often underestimated and out of place, mostly because of her gender. She is very often surrounded by tall, imposing men when doing anything in relation to the FBI (at the academy, at the autopsy, etc.). The cinematography of these scenes gives the viewer Clarice's point of view and, in comparison, she seems small and meek, perhaps unsuited for the job frequently associated with strength and masculinity. Many men in the film agree with this assessment of her. Dr. Chilton hits on her immediately, seeing her only as a sexual object purely base on her appearance. After being rebuffed, he completely changes his demeanor from friendly to cold and singlemindedly seeks to undermine her. Even Crawford, her mentor, uses her as an uninformed pawn in order to fool Dr. Lecter, ignoring her ability to consciously persuade Lecter to help them. Hannibal Lecter dismisses her as an annoyance at first before she intrigues him and, of course, Buffalo Bill merely sees women as objects to be torn apart and sewn together. All of these factors make Clarice's chosen career difficult for her to venture into and become successful purely based on her gender.

Clarice proves to be a strong, formidable woman, even to those who doubted her, by never backing down in the face of opposition. She succeeds where Dr. Chilton had failed for years in forming a connection with Hannibal Lecter and gaining his trust. Dr. Chilton, on the other hand, inadvertently allows Lecter to escape. Crawford follows a false lead to an empty house while Clarice finds Buffalo Bill by accident and kills him. This scene is one of my favorites because of what it shows about Clarice. When the lights are turned off, she is obviously terrified, frantically trying to feel her way around and listen for Buffalo Bill. The second he makes a noise, she turns and empties her gun into him and immediately reloads. It shows how she feels emotion, which is a stereotypically frowned upon trait of women, and it doesn't interfere with her ability to be a good FBI agent. Jodie Foster portrayed Clarice wonderfully with a perfect balance of toughness and vulnerability.

So many aspects of this film came together to make it exceptional. Anthony Hopkins is excellent as Hannibal Lecter with his trademark intense, unblinking stare. Ted Levine as Buffalo Bill is odd and disturbing, especially the infamous Goodbye Horses dance and the perfect delivery of "It puts the lotion on its skin." The film score by Howard Shore supports and enhances each and every scene and I can never hear Bach's Goldberg Variations the same ever again.

The Silence of the Lambs is an excellent film. I can watch it with fresh eyes and discover something new about it even after I have seen it many times over the years. It's one of those special films that transcends its time period. Sure, there are cues all over the place (clothes, phones, hair styles, etc.), but they are incidental in the face of the intensely interesting characters and the chilling plot based in reality.

I've seen this film quite a few times.  But probably for the first time last night (2012Oct19), I watched it in HD and completely uncut.  I saw the edited-for-TV version before, and the differences aren't few.  I would recommend seeing the original version again if you haven't already.

Between 1991 and today, I've seen and read quite a few true crime movies and books, and that really helps as well.  For example, the screenplay borrows from Ted Bundy:  a man with a supposed broken arm in need of help to lure his victim.  From Gary Ridgeway:  victims murdered and placed in a river.  From Ed Gein:  a guy who liked to keep trophies - in particular, skin - from his victims.  I'm quite sure that the writer of this screenplay borrowed from these true-life events.

One interesting thing that I hadn't thought about before while watching:  the Jodie Foster character is being "groomed" for her position by both her boss and Hannibal Lecter.  There are scenes where both men hold Ms. Foster's hand and there are closeups I believe on each.  This surely was intentional by the director.

While I love this film - I think that it may be the best serial killer film ever - I do think that there were issues, of course.  One of them:  most real-life serial killers look just like everybody else.  Think Mr. Bundy and Mr. Ridgeway, once again.  Really think Paul Bernardo, especially to you ladies.  Now, the killer in this film is definitely odd, and I think that he could be spotted from a mile away.  They do make reference to this at one point to be fair; Ms. Foster says something like, "Usually, transvestites are quite passive."  But still, I think that they might have been better served to have a killer who was more "normal."

But you surely can't go wrong with this excellent film, especially around Halloween.  A big recommendation by me, of course.

I truly hate this movie. It disgusts me. I'm not sure how else to put it. It touched on things that were way too real for me.

EDIT: I have decided to update my original review because I realized it was neither informative nor well-balanced, and I felt I should clarify some of my thoughts on this movie. Originally, I gave this movie a one star. I chose to add an additional star because even though the content of the movie deeply affected me (in a negative way), I can't deny that it was extremely well-made and superbly acted. It is a classic among horror films and is much higher in quality than many that exist in the genre. However, that being said, the Silence of the Lambs is not for the faint of heart. I found the movie overwhelmingly dark and heavy. It was the type of movie that stayed with me for far longer than I cared for. If you love horror movies, especially ones that are realistic and psychologically terrifying, you should totally check this movie out! If you're easily scared and disturbed (like me), this isn't the movie for you.

In my original view, I claimed that I thought the movie tried to glorify Hannibal Lecter. I felt this way watching the movie because he is portrayed as being this extremely intelligent individual who somehow possesses superhuman strength and the ability to remain a few steps ahead of every other character at all times. In other words, he is completely unmatched in skill, ability, and strength. Maybe I'm wrong, but I sort of got the feeling that audience members were supposed to admire Hannibal Lecter for these qualities, but instead I found him repulsive, soulless, and deranged.

If you're building up your DVD film library and your aim is to include the best of the best, Silence of the Lambs is definitely one of the very best films ever made. I saw this film (like most everyone else) when it was first released so many years ago. Its impact as a psychological study of psychopathic killers has not diminished over time. It still scares the wits out of me! But more importantly, it's a study in what drives serial killers and what their pathology is about. I am no movie critic but when a movie sticks in my psyche years after I see it, I conclude that it has content and a level of artistry that make it a classic. No DVD film classic library is complete without this thiller! Thanks, Amazon, for the terrific DVD selections you continue to offer! I enjoy choosing my favorites and receiving them promptly so that I can enjoy watching them again and again!

There's really no question as to why this movie got an Academy Award, the acting, scripting, and photography are all first-rate. Clarice Starling (Jody Foster) is a star pupil at the FBI training academy when her mentor, Jack Crawford (Scott Glenn) pulls her out of training to help assist on a case. Jack is the head of the Behavioral Science Unit of the FBI and he wants Clarice to interview Hannibal Lecter (Anthony Hopkins) regarding a case about a serial killer. Hannibal is known as Hannibal the Cannibal for his horrific murders in which he practiced cannibalism on his victims.

Jack thinks that Hannibal, who is a psychiatrist, could help in solving a case involving a new serial killer called Buffalo Bill by using his insight into serial killers and psychiatry. Buffalo Bill kills women and skins parts of their bodies. Hannibal is angry that Jack sent a newbie young woman agent to try to entice him to talk. He won't help but when Clarice is leaving and is soiled by one of the other prisoners he agrees to help her. Hannibal's clues lead her to evidence of an old murder and to a possible link between Hannibal and Buffalo Bill. Hannibal's leads help the investigation but also turn into severe complications....

This movie is about the evil that men can do and of a young agent becoming exposed to the world of the criminally insane. Many scenes are macabre and horrifying so if you don't like those types of movies then you should consider if this movie is for you. It is truly a crime and horror classic movie and the acting is superb. The story line is very tightly done and directed expertly and the movie was a box office hit as well as the winner of multiple academy awards.

It is a very good movie and I recommend it to you, just remember it is deep and ghastly film!

A classic. Simply one of the all-time master pieces of the film making industry.

Jodie Foster and Anthony Hopkins performances are so smooth and real that it is not too hard to feel empathy mixed with fear throughout the development of the story. For sure, worthy of those Oscars.

Silence of the Lambs has a reputation for horrific violence, but the movie version is one that even the squeamish should be able to watch with only a few eye-coverings. Foster is a FBI trainee who is trying to help track down a serial killer. Hopkins is a captured killer who knows how these people think. Over time Foster is drawn to Hopkins, Hopkins subtly manipulates Foster, and the killer keeps doing his thing. Will Foster track the loose bad guy down in time?

I normally tend to shy away from gruesome movies - but I've seen Silence of the Lambs multiple times and adored it each time. It absolutely deserves its #65 ranking on the AFI top 100. The plot is fantastic and draws you in right from the very beginning. The actors are all fantastic. From Foster to Hopkins, from Levine to Glenn, you see their twist of motivations, their pulls and concerns, and how the relationships build.

Interwoven with the main plot are a variety of sub-themes. I love the scenes that examine the role of men and women in the police / FBI forces. They are handled very deftly. When Foster is presented, she's shown as a strong, athletically talented, intellectually gifted woman. And even so, the men around her look at her and see her beauty. The criminal she passes is crude in how he deals with her. Glenn is both a mentor and interested in her as a woman. The fellow male trainees all turn to watch her as she jogs past. When she and Glenn go to a crime scene, he "protects" her and draws the Sheriff to the side in order to discuss a sensitive topic. Foster is calm, deliberate, and points out the issue to Glenn. He acknowledges that she is right.

Out of all the movies in the AFI top 100, this is amazingly probably the best one in terms of female characters! With all the great movies on this list - Gone with the Wind, Annie Hall, Doctor Zhivago, that feature strong women, it's Silence of the Lambs that features some of the best women-to-women discussions in the entire list. In the vast majority of movies on the AFI list the women are solely there to play against men. They only ever talk with men. But here Foster has a sharp, wise African-American female friend who shares her insight into situations.

There are so many ways in which this movie shines. The plot is engaging and insightful. The actors are masters of their crafts. The tension in the scenes is masterfully handled.

Highly recommended.

My Fav movie of all time!
Saw this movie after my 12th grade final exams. Amazing and worth the wait!
Hopkins, Jodie and the music are phenomenal!

Jonathan Demme's 1991 masterpiece The Silence of the Lambs is a film that, once seen, will last in your memory forever. It's a powerful study of good vs evil told though the eyes of a young FBI trainee named Clarice Starling, our sympathetic heroine who is embodied by Jodie Foster heart and soul in the best performace of her career. She is called on by FBI Agent Jack Crawford to interrogate the brilliant psychopath Dr. Hannibal Lecter in hopes of gaining information on another serial killer, Buffalo Bill, one of Dr. Lecter's former patients. Anthony Hopkins is brilliant and terrifying in his role of the cannibalistic Dr. Lecter, and his relationship with Foster's Clarice Starling is one of the most interesting put on film of which I can think. Screenwriter Ted Tally does a masterful job of adapting Thomas Harris' novel and director Demme maintains a fever pitch atmosphere throughout. Foster and Hopkins are two of our best living actors, and they are at the top of their game here. Howard Shore's moody and atmospheric musical score compliments the film perfectly. The Silence of the Lambs is a masterpiece, thrilling and entertaining, and a film everyone should see at least once. A+
Jody Foster and Anthony Hopkins give performances of a lifetime and Buffalo Bill is chillingly believable as well. This is a great horror movie.
I rented this movie as a research tool for a play I was costuming. I was reluctant to watch it, but ended up engrossed and fascinated. It is a really good, and well done film.

It's rare for a film to win Best Actor, Best Actress, Best Picture, Best Director and Best Screenplay Oscars, but The Silence of the Lambs did just that. Hannibal Lecter (Hopkins) is often regarded at the top villain in cinema history and he's probably the first character that springs to mind when you think about the movie. It's hard to believe that Hopkins was only on the screen for about 16 minutes.

The story begins with Agent Clarice Starling (Foster). We see her tackling an obstacle course at the FBI's Quantico training center. Her boss, Jack Crawford, (Glenn), calls her in and asks her to visit Lecter. He's in a secure cell and the warnings she receives appear excessive, but they seem justified by the end of the movie.

Lecter is intelligent, polite and eloquent. Although he's a monster capable of eating people, he has a twisted sense of honor. It's clear that he likes Starling and he rewards some of her honest revelations with help and insight into how she might track down serial killer, Buffalo Bill (Ted Levine).

It's curious that the movie is often placed in the horror genre. I watched David Fincher's version of The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo recently, and compared the two films. Both are essentially investigations into murders as the protagonists attempt to track a serial killer. Each includes a colorful character, although one is a hero and the other a villain. If Lisbeth Salander and Hannibal Lecter were more conventional characters, the two movies would lose a lot of their power. I think it's wrong to label The Silence of the Lambs as a horror movie, but I understand why that's often the case.

The movie works because we love how monstrous Lecter is and how human Starling can be. Foster's performance made Starling seem incredibly vulnerable. She's a young cadet finding her way in the FBI and this is her first big break. Then we see that she has to contend with Lecter, who is ruthlessly insightful and able to read her easily. Much of the story is seen from Starling's point of view and it's easy to identify with her fears as she tries to catch the killer.

The final showdown is extremely effective. You can sense the evil in Buffalo Bill and Starling's fear is audible and visible. The song playing during this sequence (Hip Priest, by The Fall) holds special meaning for me as it was played at the first concert I ever attended.

Scott Glenn can be very likable and I enjoyed his performance as Crawford. The movie drew considerable praise from the FBI for it's realism and it was easy to imagine Glenn as a member of the organization.

Hopkins is a versatile actor capable of playing just about any role. I would rank him among the top tier of my favorite actors. Maybe it's because of the characters he plays, but he strikes me as a very intelligent man.

The Silence of the Lambs is constructed simply, but the acting and the ominous mood elevate it to the level of greatness.

A supposed "thriller" that gets laughs in all the wrong places, this seems destined to be relegated to "Bad Movie Night" festivals and 99-cent rental bins. Foster is adequate, but I can't help wondering what Lauren Tewes ('Julie' on THE LOVE BOAT) could have done with the role. As for Hopkins, his last great performance was in FREEJACK, and his work here is more than worthy of a Golden Turkey Award. And was the wall-to-wall ABBA music REALLY necessary?? For a real thriller, check out Brian DePalma's DRESSED TO KILL; 'SILENCE' doesn't even rate a "guilty pleasure."
Love this movie and I'm not usually a fan of horror at all. Great acting all the way. I particularly enjoyed the added features on this special edition.

The movie still cries out even today...A five star production and top notch acting by some of the great thespians of our time.

Everything is here except for one thing: a believable psychopath, taken here in the form of Hannibal Lecter, an impossibly unrealistic antivillain that defies reality to the point where it's so distracting to be destructive.

Again, everything is here. The cinematography, writing, pacing, all of it's there. The only problem is the character of Hannibal Lecter, an apparently supernatural being who is not just a psychopath, but also a genius. But while I admit that some psychopaths are extremely intelligent, none can smell someone else from fifteen feet away and determine their perfume. Hannibal Lecter is so over-the-top, it's just awful. He's not at all a realistic psychopath, and is just a dramatic representation of what some of us might believe to be a psychopath. Instead, he's seen as having pretty much supernatural powers, which is just unforgivable here. The main antagonist is far more believable, although rather stupid, considering the ending in which he dies by his own stupidity.

Knowing psychopathy, I can't forgive this film's portrayal of Lecter, who is so far beyond the real psychopath that it's just comical, even funny at times. I genuinely smiled in amusement as he did things that no one could do, including psychopaths. It was awful. There's a reason no one like him exists: Because they don't. Psychopaths simply aren't capable of what Lecter does here, and it stretches the boundaries of what they can do too far to be enjoyable. Sure, I understand it's a movie, but movies have to stay in reality at least to a reasonable extent. This film doesn't do that. Lecter is beyond unbelievable, and an extremely poor example of even the most intelligent psychopath, particularly considering that he apparently has superhuman powers.

I had very high hopes for this film. I'm very sorry I was disappointed after picking up the Blu-ray. Lecter ruins it rather than makes it, but it's not Hopkins' fault, it's the writer's, who just doesn't care what he's writing about. Clearly, no research was done here, and everything was just made up for dramatic effect. For most of us, that's okay, but for those of us who are more educated to know what psychopathy is, it's just a killjoy.

Very disappointing because of Lecter's superhuman skills that make no sense whatsoever, and are not entertaining. Also major points off for the ending, in which you wonder you wonder how others were killed when hunted by the antagonist if he's so stupid as to do what he does at the end. It's extremely unsatisfying, and betrays horribly the methodical style of him. Just, awful.

This movie was creepy and disgusting. It made me feel uncomfortable throughout the film and even for a long time afterwards. Despite that, I thought it was a brilliant work of cinema! I'm a bit weak when it comes to handling movies with gore, violence, and all of that, and of course I wouldn't be a fan of seeing these issues in real life...nobody would, hopefully, unless they're a lot like Buffalo Bill ;). But I thought the suspense buildup at various points of the movie were like no other. The actors, particularly Jodie Foster and Anthony Hopkins, played their parts well, despite what anyone might say against Foster's accent. And Hannibal was full of hair-raising tricks that justified the amount of heavy security placed near his cell.

Even if you don't like this movie that much, you would have to admit that it is a lot better than some of the more recent so-called "thrillers" that have been out in theaters. This one has realistic (albeit melancholy) situations, and isn't afraid to be a little bold in the topics covered. There might have been some aspects of the movie that weren't exactly necessary, but the movie was great anyway. If you have the guts to sit through the R-rated situations (violence, nudity, and intense situations), this is definitely one you need to watch.

I was skeptical, prior to watching the film, that it would stand up to the hype and acclaim heaped upon it by both critics and the Academy. Seeing how both have lavished acclaim on films that did not deserve it, I was hoping this was a rare case of Hollywood delivering. From the get go, I found the plot to be fairly predictable. I am not certain if this is due to more recent fare lifting ideas from the film, or if the film follows a typical by-the-numbers structure; surprisingly, this did not deter me from stopping the film. I was very much intrigued by Jodie Foster's performance. Like Dr. Lecter, I, too, wanted to know more about Clarice's background. I found Hopkins' performance tolerable; it was his constant snake-hissing that lent his character a cartoony feel and was thus difficult to take seriously at times. Overall, the film was entertaining. However, I would not revisit it or seek any greater meaning or subplot in it. Quick little note: has anyone noticed that the soundtrack consists of a track by the Fall and another by Colin Newman of Wire fame? I thought that was the best thing about this film, actually.

I love "The Silence of the Lambs." It is one of my favorite movies. As one reviewer said, she enjoyed movies that (pull you in) so that you feel far, far away. I totally agree. "Lambs" stands head and shoulders above other horror movies because it is done with class and believability, unlike others that just feature repeated scenes of gore. I found "Lambs" to be spooky rather than unwatchably scary, because of these qualities. Jodie Foster's and Anthony Hopkin's acting are superb, getting inside Lecter's mind portrays the true, calculated nature of evil at its worst rather than just scenes of gore for shock value. The scene where he asks Miss Starling if she ever saved her lamb has such spiritual resonance i almost cried. Clarice is warned to not let Lecter get into her mind, and, in her fear and duty, deems the revealing of her thoughts necessary to the capturing of Buffalo Bill, with chilling results.

Other reviewers complained about Jodie Foster's "forced" southern accent. No, it was not indicative of Virginia where Clarice Starling had grown up during early childhood, and, while it sounds like she is imitating Reba McEntire, a southern accent is hard to imitate perfectly if one is not a native southerner (Foster is a native of L.A.), so give her a break. We can overlook this small, but cute error seeing as it is does not overshadow a brilliant storyline.

Everything is brilliant from beginning to end, from Clarice's revealing of her mind setting the stage to Hannibal's escape, to the very real threat of young women with kind personalities being the perfect target for rape and murder, to ultimately, evil being triumphed by good as our heroic rookie takes on Buffalo Bill, to the chilling cliffhanger of our escaped villain, Lecter.

I am not really a fan of the horror genre but loved this movie and i think others will agree. A must see for any fan of top-notch movie making, deep story line, and the a true portrayal of good and evil.

This film has acquired classic status on the thriller / horror genre. In IMDB it is 8.7. But, in fact, Silence of the Lambs is an overrated movie, to a degree comparable with Poltergeist. There are many problems in this film (both 'structural', as 'occasional'):

1) Accent terribly uncomfortable from Clarice Starling (Foster).
2) Hopkins overacting: unwillingly, Hannibal Lecter, in various parts of the film takes shape too comical and ridiculous - the same thing happens with 'Buffalo Bill "(one of the most mediocre serial killers of all time).
3) Buffalo Bill: concentrates a multitude of clichs. It is a very poor character.
4) The idea of the moth is too melodramatic, having its reflection in the "transformation " and "maturity" of Clarice ( la Disney World).
5) Characters totally unnecessary and incoherent with the atmosphere of the film (the colleague of Clarice at the Academy, the pair of "funny" biologists, for example).
6) Childish clichs regarding psychiatry and psychology.
7) Hannibal Lecter is a sort of superman: unlocks all mysteries, makes jests ("love your suit"...), gives a beating in the police (despite being locked up for eight years he maintened strong and muscled), deceives many doctors by placing a mask of flesh.
8) improbabilities: this is probably the biggest problem the film. There are many: a) Hannibal Lecter opens his handcuffs with a piece of pen b) Clarice Starling in 10 seconds, stirring a random object from one of the victims of "Buffalo Bill", founds revealing photos, c) Hannibal Lecter knows everything about everyone despite being locked in an underground hospital for some years, d) Hannibal Lecter kills a guy whispering (can someone explain this?)
9) The story of the murders becomes uninteresting throughout the film.
10) the end couldn't be worse.

&c.
